title: Neil Black to stand down from UK Athletics role amid Salazar fallout
text:
• Performance director to leave at the end of October • Black will still oversee Mo Farah’s run at Chicago marathon

Neil Black will stand down as UK Athletics performance director at the end of October, the governing body has announced.

Black, who had said he would review his position after the American coach Alberto Salazar was banned by the United States Anti-Doping Agency, will still oversee Mo Farah’s involvement in the Chicago Marathon as planned this weekend.

Neil Black considering his UKA position after Alberto Salazar doping ban Read more

A statement from UK Athletics read: “UK Athletics have announced that Neil Black will leave his role as performance director at the end of October. Neil will commence a detailed handover with performance staff until his departure and will fulfil his role supporting Mo Farah at this weekend’s Chicago marathon.”

Black revealed on Monday that he was considering his position following Salazar’s four-year ban for doping offences. Black is not implicated in any wrongdoing but his judgment has come under question because of his unstinting support for Salazar, who coached Farah for nearly seven years and was a British Athletics consultant until 2017.

Speaking for the first time since Salazar was banned, Black said: “I’ll be personally reviewing thoughts that I had, the decisions I’ve made, the things that I’ve said. Having done that thoroughly, patiently, sensibly, I’ll come to my own decision and that will run in parallel with discussions with UKA chair Chris Clark and the board.”

Of Farah, who has always denied any wrongdoing, Black said: “Nothing at all has changed in terms of my belief regarding Mo Farah. I think it is important to repeat that the British Athletics medical and support teams were always the people who were always on top of, and managing and directing the care of Mo Farah, so we have no concerns.”
